description.text:
Allows printing of 8 to 16 colors of filament without swapping spools, and without using more than 3/4" (yes inch!) of desk space.
Also makes your printer much lighter if you've been mounting filament spools on the back.

1) Print one or two 8x filament through holes.
2) Print one to four wall mount filament retainer brackets.
3) Print desired number of filament clips. 4) Drill one (8 colors) or two (16 colors) 3/4" holes below the filament intake of your Replicator (or other 3D printer). 5) Place through hole filament guide into 3/4" hole. For a friction fit, try wrapping with a layer or two of masking tape. 6) Install spools using desired mounting method. My method: I used 5/8" round dowel covered with 5/8" HDPE tubing (my local brand name is Pex, from Home Depot) which I split down one side so it would snap over the wood dowel. I used some carbon fiber rod to keep the spools from touching each other and from falliing off the dowels. This was glued into holes drilled through the pex and into the round dowel and the appropriate spacing for my spools. I really like the double-length dowels on the left in my picture. They worked very well and hold a lot of filament in a small area. I drilled some 41/64" (about 16mm) holes into a 2x2 and press fit the round dowels. Mind that the spacing of your holes works for your spool size. The 2x2 is then screwed to the wall or back of cabinet. I installed my at a slightly outward angle so the spools would spin against the carbon stops and not against the 2x2 (less friction). 7) Load up the spool holder with all of your filament. Feed filament from the underside of the spools into the middle (below the 3/4" hole). 8) Install the wall mount filament retainer bracket behind and conveniently above your 3D printer. Route filament from the spools into the guide, and up to the wall mount filament retainer bracket. Clip into place. 9) Print, swap colors, print, swap colors. Enjoy 8CFDS. http://tinkercad.com/things/81cxG5i5QhV-wall-mount-holder-for-175mm-filament
http://tinkercad.com/things/2OXuqlhHdFY-175mm-8x-filament-guide-through-hole

comments.text: You should integrate a one-way pinch so that the filament draws up easily but can just be released without sliding back down.Â  There are a few ways to do it:Â  An angled spring flap pointing up, a sloped channel for a ball bearing (or bb) to roll down and bind when pulled backwards...

disruptit's broom holder is a great idea, but its only one size, and I found my various brooms and mops had enough variation to not all fit.  Also, it prints with the flanges pointing up, so its flexing against the layer grain and tends to crack.
I redesigned the same basic shape as a parametric openscad object.  Just measure the broom you want to hang and change the dimensions to match.  It also prints standing on end so as not to crack along layers.

Change the variables at the beginning of the scad file to match your broom, render and print.  The parameters already there are set for a fairly typical broom, and standard drywall screws.  The screw holes are recessed to keep the screw head from getting in the way of the broom, so make sure they are the right size for your screw.

title: Nema 17 Motor Fan Shroud for Greg's Hinged Accessible Extruder (MakerFarm Prusa i3 i3v)

description.text:
This fan shroud allows you to mount a 40mm fan to cool your NEMA 17 extruder motor without blowing air on the bed or printed parts.  It's specifically designed to fit on the MakerFarm Prusa i3 and i3v, but it should fit any printer that uses Greg's Hinged Accessible Extruder.  
It will print unsupported on most printers with the fan attachment plate face-down down on the bed.  
The shroud has eight internal channels that pull air in through the ports on the bottom, smoothly across two sides of the motor and exhaust it out the top, away from the bed.  
It mounts to the motor with a single zip tie, passing through the air channels and the provided hole in the center divider.   
Some fans create tubulence and a loud whine as the leading edges of the blades pass across the edges of the partitions in the shroud.  If yours does this, a spacer plate is also provided to mount between the fan and the shroud.   
See the instructions for details.

This fan shroud is sized to fit the standard motors that ship with the MakerFarm Prusa i3 and i3v kits.  If you're using different motors, the fit may vary.  
The mount is designed for a 40mm fan.  Attach it with the air flow exhausting upward using four M3 screws.  The holes are sized to be tapped with an M3 tap.  No drilling should be necessary.  The holes are only 10mm deep, to avoid disturbing the air flow in the interior.  If your screws are longer, you can always drill the holes through to the interior air passages.  
Snap the shroud over the motor as shown in the photos.  Attach it with a zip tie passed through the second port from the wire side of the motor.  There's a small opening in the center air divider to the zip tie to pass through.  
Once the shroud is mounted, use a zip tie to attach your extruder motor and hot end wires to the tab.  There's a notch in the back side of the tab opposite the hole to keep the zip tie from slipping off.  I've provided a generous amount of space to accommodate extra wires for a motor, heater, thermistor, Z probe, servo, fans, lights, etc.  
You will want a fan that can move plenty of air.  If your fan makes a loud whining noise, you may wish to print out a spacer to put between the fan and the shroud to allow the airflow to consolidate and reduce turbulence.  An output funnel is also provided to decelerate the air exiting the fan and reduce the chances of air off the edges of the fan making its way back down to the bed.

comments.text: This is a beautiful model, and printed nicely (Simplify3D, 0.22 mm layers, 0.35 mm nozzle, 0.40 mm extrusion), but, sadly, it doesn't fit on the TAZ 4 I printed it on/for. For anyone considering this for their LulzBot printer; this does not fit the NEMA 17 stepper motors used by LulzBot! Oh well, I'll save it for future projects.

Ok, I thought it was more of a theoretical issue, not a real enough issue that people actually get the extruder to melt and need something to prevent it!
I got my kit last year, but it's all the standard motors that makerfarm ships, I think the difference is that I use the RAMBo board instead of RAMPS, and I spent some time fine tuning the current so the motors get the lowest possible current without getting any missed steps. The result was that it's barely warm to the touch after hours of printing, but my main purpose was to make it stop doing that high pitch noise which was driving me nuts :p
I knew it was easier to configure the current with RAMBo since it has the digital potentiometer and I could set the current value with Pronterface, but I thought you could still get similar results with the pololu potentiometer, just that it takes longer and is more annoying to do.
I bought a prusa i3v now which I should get tomorrow, then I'll print all of your upgrades because it looks amazing all you've done. The only thing missing now for the makerfarm is for someone to design a dual extruder solution :)

comments.author: ResistImpulse

comments.text:
Clough 42,
I like your work. I have made one of your improved end stop pieces for my Prusa 10" i3V. I have yet to find a CAD application for designing that feels natural for me. I am open to suggestions.
I read the comment below about this shroud design rejecting less heat than a fan mounted without a shroud. I would suggest keeping in the forefront of design that heat exchange increases with the amount of surface area you have contacting your fluid (air). A few other factors play a part as well but lets stick to surface area. My background in heating ventilation and air conditioning has drilled the concepts to the core of me.
For deeper ideas and examples lets look at current methods of heat exchange. You have coils in your indoor residential air handler for A/C. This coil is typically very close straight fins that have a blower and a filter prior in the air flow to protect these close fins from getting filled with dirt. Outdoor coils for the condenser have the same design. As you get into commercial units they will begin adding a bend into these fins and stacking the coils deeper. You will also begin to see rifling on the inside of the copper tubes which the refrigerant travels through so that the refrigerant side of the surface area has an increase.
Now look back to residential outdoor coils that have begun, in the past several years, stepping away from the fins and moved to these spiky or hair like design which further increases the surface area.
To bring it back to simple example and visual we move from the surface area of the potato to the increased surface area by cutting the potato into thin slices, then we land on increasing it further by cutting those potato slices so we have thin french fry-esque lengths.
CONCLUSION:
I think you -may- benefit from trying to add some more plastic that touches the motor body and then comes away from the body into the air stream. I am uncertain about the comparison of heat exchange between the plastic and motor or plastic and air, but I would imagine none of the above are great and this could be worth a try if you are looking to tinker a bit more. You could also increase the number of channels. The easiest modification I saw that may increase the efficiency would be to change the suction or input side of the design. You currently have end flush with the motor shape if a line were to extend. I think it would be great to add a piece that forces the fresh air to be drawn past the motor form the beginning. You essentially can be channeling fresh air to whoosh by the motor without much chance to exchange heat. By drawing from the motor with as little fresh air mixing in then you will surely force the fresh air by the hot motor then up and outward.
Also, I would be more than willing to chat with you about this because I am struggling to design but I have the knowledge about heat that may aid your design abilities.
comments.author: ResistImpulse

comments.text:
I agree that the fan shroud could be more efficient, but I'm generally happy with how well it works. As I commented earlier, it's possible to get better cooling by just blowing the fan directly on the motor, but the advantage of the shroud is that it contains the airflow and keeps it from spilling onto the print.
The real culprit here, I'm convinced, is the motor current. The MakerFarm motors are really only .5A motors, but the instructions call for setting the current quite a bit higher than this. Fortunately, since it's a 9V motor, it isn't possible to draw up to the set current limit. Stock, the motors are pulling about 150% of their rating, which doesn't seem to kill them, but does lead to heating problems and melted or warped extruders. I have since designed a NEMA 14-based belted extruder that I'm really liking. With the current set properly for the NEMA 14 motor, I'm not even using a fan at all. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:389105http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
I do like your thinking regarding increasing the surface area for the air-motor interaction. This is the basic theory behind most heat sink designs. Unfortunately, ABS plastic makes a terrible heat sink material. The thermal conductivity of the motor body is probably around 36W/m.K. A proper aluminum heat sink would be greater than 200W/m.K. ABS is basically an insulator at 0.19W/m.K.
comments.author: ResistImpulse

comments.text:
This is a dicey part that requires a decently-calibrated printer to print well. I'm using ABS with .2mm layer height using a .4mm nozzle and I'm slicing it with Slic3r 1.0.1 stable. You will really need good retraction because there is a lot of detail on separate islands near the top.
The plates that sit on the bottom motor edges (when installed) are delicate. Once the shroud is installed and strapped down, it is enough. The wall thickness is 1.2mm throughout. I don't really want to compromise the airflow. This already doesn't cool as well as a fan blowing on the motor in free air. The big win with the shroud is that it completely contains the air and doesn't direct anything onto the bed. Which areas need to be thicker?

comments.text: Only that guy doesn't work as well on the i3v. You've got the mount plate in front, and the Y axis extrusion behind the motor. I keep thinking about designing a 40mm fan mount that mounts on v-slot or t-slot.
comments.author: AJMetal87

comments.text: That's a great idea.  You could probably design it so it snaps into the slot.  I bet you could get it to hold well enough to not need a screw or T-nut.
comments.author: AbuMaia

comments.text: I wouldn't trust it without the t-nut and m5 bolt. I was thinking of modifying one of your endstop holders, if I could figure out how to modify .stls.
comments.author: clough42

comments.text: You can load .stl files into Openscad and then add or remove structures.  I've heard of people using CG tools like Blender to do it as well.  Straight up CAD tools don't really like STL as an input format, but sometimes you can make it work.
comments.author: AbuMaia

comments.text: I think I've got it...
comments.author: clough42

comments.text: It's pretty close.  It may be a better fit on the i3 than the i3v, because of the screws mounting the sub-plate on the i3v.  The X and Y motors are on my list.  The Y is really sandwiched in there.  The good news is that both of those motors are mounted to materials that can handle high temperatures.  In ambient air, mine only get to 65C or so max, which is okay.  If you've got an enclosed chamber, it'll be more of a challenge.
comments.author: AbuMaia

title: wifi serial adapter case - (RN370 or wisnap)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This case provides additional protection to a Microchip RN370 AAA serial to wifi dongle(same as wisnap AAA dongle).  
This covers up the dip configuration switches and the momentary button but once configured these aren't really required since the device awakens automatically when it senses serial traffic.  
A sliding part in the cover allows for access to the power port while keeping it protected when not charging the unit.  
I used a female wifi dongle with a gender changer screwed to the printed cover which gave me a male serial port.  The jumpers inside the module were also changed to reflect this.  
The case provides significant protection compared to the stock case while also making it so no loads are transferred to the circuit board through the serial port.  The case also provides some protection against moisture.

(1) Print out all three parts.
Natural PLA is best that way you can still see which LED status lights are on.
(2) Screw mini gender changer to top cover.
(3) Insert sliding cover part into bottom part groove.
(4) Insert serial wifi adapter into bottom case so power port lines up with access port.
(5) Assemble top cover to bottom cover and bolt together using 4 6X 1/2in metal screws.
